node.title: 'You can't be Aboriginal': Winner of the Dr Charles Perkins Prize says don't let others define who you are
node.alt: A man smiles as he holds a framed black and white photograph
node.description: Benjamin Wilson dismissed slurs he was told at school and instead focused on storytelling and learning – which now sees him named a recipient of the Dr Charles Perkins Memorial Prize.
node.content:
["\"You\u00a0can't be Aboriginal, you're too smart for that,\" Benjamin Wilson was told when he was at school.", "But the 23-year-old Wiradjuri man dismissed those slurs\u00a0and instead focused on storytelling and learning \u2014 which has seen him named a recipient of the Dr Charles Perkins Memorial Prize.", "\"I think that's because I had really strong role modelling from my family and the people around me,\" he said.", "One of those strong role models is his 84-year-old grandmother, Elsie Heiss, who instilled in him a love of learning and reading, as well as resilience and a strong work ethic.", "\"At 16, she hopped on the train at Griffith to Shepparton in Victoria, to go and work in a fruit cannery,\" he said, \"that kind of drive has always been in my family\".", "That drive is also clear in Benjamin \u2014 and why he has been named a recipient of the Dr Charles Perkins Memorial Prize at Sydney University, for excelling at his studies in a Bachelor of Arts in Media and Communications.", "
Who was Charles Perkins?
", "", "
Charles Perkins talking with Aboriginal residents in Moree, NSW, during the Freedom Ride in 1965.(Supplied: State Library of NSW)
", "Dr Charles Perkins AO was a ground-breaking civil rights activist, academic, and public servant.", "The Arrernte and Kalkadoon man led the 1965 Freedom Rides, a movement that travelled across regional Australia to raise awareness for the equal rights of First Nations people.", "The rides helped sway public opinion in the 1967 referendum, where the nation voted overwhelmingly to change the constitution in favour of addressing inequalities for Indigenous people.", "Dr Perkins was also the first Aboriginal man to graduate from the University of Sydney and he later became the first Indigenous person to lead the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.", "At his state funeral in 2000, he was remembered by former prime minister Malcolm Fraser as a man who worked relentlessly for his people.", "The awards would usually be presented in a ceremony in the University's great hall, but as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and ensuing restrictions, that wasn't possible this year.", "Filmmaker, director and screenwriter Rachel Perkins is the daughter of the late Dr Perkins\u00a0and announced the recipients of the awards.", "", "
Charles Perkins and other members of the Freedom Ride at Bowraville, NSW, in 1965.(Supplied:\u00a0State Library of New South Wales)
", "\"When my Dad was at university in 1965, he was one of three Indigenous students in the whole country,\" she said, \"today, there are literally thousands of Indigenous students who graduated and are currently studying at Australia's Universities.\"", "\"Dad talked about keeping the fire in the belly \u2014 he never accepted that Indigenous people should be second-class citizens in their own country.\"", "Ms Perkins introduced Tony McAvoy SC, Australia's first Indigenous silk, to present the Dr Charles Perkins Oration, describing the respected legal leader as \"a contemporary warrior\".", "Mr McAvoy said Dr Perkins was an \"extraordinary person \u2026 who achieved greatness in his lifetime\".", "\"His legacy also lives on through his contributions to education, sport, housing, and public life, but to name a few areas of his endeavour.\"", "
'Dr Perkins was such an inspiration'
", "\"It's a massive honour to be awarded the prize with the other two recipients,\" Benjamin said.", "Benjamin said the late Dr Perkins was a trailblazer who paved the way for other Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students.", "\"Now, we have our students in these academic environments \u2014 we know that we do belong there, that we are smart, and we do have something of value to contribute.\"", "", "
Charles Perkins had graduated from university before even being counted in the census as a person.(Supplied: University of Sydney)
", "
Dr Perkins' legacy encourages us all to challenge perceptions
", "Benjamin is an LGBTQIA+ man and has advocated for greater awareness of the intersectionality of being gay and Aboriginal.", "\"I think the Aboriginal identity gets pigeon-holed into this one media representation, and if you don't fit into that, you are an anomaly or the outlier,\" he said.", "\"Since Invasion, Aboriginal men have been represented as hyper-masculine \u2026 that's fed into the idea that all of our men need to be warriors; the protector; super blokey-blokey.", "\"But you know, if I'm strutting down Oxford Street in a pair of heels, I'm still a warrior, I'm just going to do it with my nails painted.\"", "", "
Benjamin wants to encourage young people to become role models for others.(Supplied)
", "
By being visible, Dr Perkins created change
", "\"I think that's something that young people like myself have, the ability to make ourselves so visible in our advocacy,\" Benjamin said.", "\"Whenever we do that, in a public way, it's making a contribution and providing role models for someone else.\"", "Benjamin said Indigenous people shouldn't be held back by what others think of them.", "\"Use that as a fire underneath you,\" he said.", "\"Prove everyone wrong \u2014 that's what I did.", "\"Everyone has a sense of not belonging \u2014 there are support systems there, you just have to seek them out.", "\"We shouldn't be deterred by not feeling good enough, because we absolutely are good enough.\"", "Watch the 2021 Dr Charles Perkins Memorial Oration\u00a0on ABC Iview."]
